question.text: All the components of the nodal tissue are autoexcitable. Why does the SA node act as the normal pacemaker?

options.text: SA node has the lowest rate of depolarisation
SA node is the only component to generate the threshold potential
Only SA node can convey the action potential to the other components
SA node has the highest rate of depolarisation

solution.text: The nodal musculature has the ability to generate action potentials without any external stimuli, i.e. it is autoexcitable. However, the number of action potentials that could be generated in a minute vary at different parts of the nodal system. The SAN (Sino-Atrial Node) can generate the maximum number of action potentials, i.e $70-75 \mathrm{~min}$, i.e. the highest rate of depolarisation and is responsible for initiating and maintaining the rhythmic contractile activity of the heart. Therefore, it is called pacemaker.
